  16. (** Function manipulation.

  18.     @since 4.08 *)

  20. (** {1:combinators Combinators} *)

  22. external id : 'a -> 'a = "%identity"
  23. (** [id] is the identity function. For any argument [x], [id x] is [x]. *)

  25. ‌val const : 'a -> (_ -> 'a)
  26. (** [const c] is a function that always returns the value [c]. For any
  27.     argument [x], [(const c) x] is [c]. *)

  29. ‌val flip : ('a -> 'b -> 'c) -> ('b -> 'a -> 'c)
  30. (** [flip f] reverses the argument order of the binary function
  31.     [f]. For any arguments [x] and [y], [(flip f) x y] is [f y x]. *)

  33. ‌val negate : ('a -> bool) -> ('a -> bool)
  34. (** [negate p] is the negation of the predicate function [p]. For any
  35.     argument [x], [(negate p) x] is [not (p x)]. *)

  37. (** {1:exception Exception handling} *)

  39. ‌val protect : finally:(unit -> unit) -> (unit -> 'a) -> 'a
  40. (** [protect ~finally work] invokes [work ()] and then [finally ()]
  41.     before [work ()] returns with its value or an exception. In the
  42.     latter case the exception is re-raised after [finally ()]. If
  43.     [finally ()] raises an exception, then the exception
  44.     {!Finally_raised} is raised instead.

  46.     [protect] can be used to enforce local invariants whether [work ()]
  47.     returns normally or raises an exception. However, it does not
  48.     protect against unexpected exceptions raised inside [finally ()]
  49.     such as {!Stdlib.Out_of_memory}, {!Stdlib.Stack_overflow}, or
  50.     asynchronous exceptions raised by signal handlers
  51.     (e.g. {!Sys.Break}).

  53.     Note: It is a {e programming error} if other kinds of exceptions
  54.     are raised by [finally], as any exception raised in [work ()] will
  55.     be lost in the event of a {!Finally_raised} exception. Therefore,
  56.     one should make sure to handle those inside the finally. *)

  58. exception Finally_raised of exn
  59. (** [Finally_raised exn] is raised by [protect ~finally work] when
  60.     [finally] raises an exception [exn]. This exception denotes either
  61.     an unexpected exception or a programming error. As a general rule,
  62.     one should not catch a [Finally_raised] exception except as part of
  63.     a catch-all handler. *)
